text: [Music] good morning Singapore thank all of you for spending
some time with us today I realize what a commitment it is for you to take a day out of your busy schedules and we really
appreciate you being here today I've been honored to have the privilege to meet with so many brilliant companies
here in Singapore over the past week and I feel quite humbled to be able to speak with all of you this morning like all of
our events today's sum is much more of a Learning and Development experience than it is a sales and marketing conference
we're going to hold several sessions covering a variety of topics for those of you with all levels of experim
experience and our goal is that you leave here today with a much better understanding of how AWS can help you
achieve your business goals in addition to these sessions I'd really encourage you to use today as an opportunity to
network with your peers there's nearly 2,000 companies represented here today
many of whom are using technology in some very amazing ways to transform their business this explosion and Cloud
adoption is one of the many reasons that I decided to dedicate this chapter of my career to
AWS and I'm I continue to be amazed with how fast the community is growing if
you're just getting started with the cloud there's no time like the present when I started using AWS in 2012 when I
was at Dow Jones the community wasn't nearly this big so the cloud has introduced a seismic
shift in the way companies of all sizes consume it and has made way for
thousands of businesses both both new businesses as well as established businesses to innovate in ways never
before possible so I'm fortunate enough to meet with Venture capitalists from time to time and they all agree that AWS
has allowed them to diversify their vest Investments across far more companies
than ever before and has opened the door for wellestablished Industries to be
disrupted in a very meaningful way and so while we're very excited by the growth that we've seen in the business
over the last nine years the founders of AWS certainly did not predict that it
would happen this fast so let's take a look at some of the metrics that help illustrate this seismic
shift Amazon's simple storage service otherwise known as S3 was the first ever
cloud-based object storage launched in 2006 the growth we've seen in S3 has
been simply staggering we used to talk about the trillions of objects that have
come in and out of the platform but as that number became larger and larger it became perhaps a little bit less
meaningful as an illustration of growth so this year we instead looked at the amount of data that was transferred in
and out of the platform and we've seen a year-over-year increase of 102% and that exclud includes any of the
usage that we've seen inside of Amazon we see a similar story when we
talk about the growth of Amazon's elastic compute Cloud otherwise known as ec2 again if we exclude any internal
Amazon use we have a year over-year growth of 93% of the number of compute
hours used on a already very large base this growth again is just simply
staggering and in case you are wondering if this growth has been dominated by just a few customers growing very large
I'm very happy to report to you that last year we crossed the 1 million active customer Mark now we Define an
active customer as any customer who's had account activity in their account in the last 30 days so all of these
trajectories are very encouraging for a business that's only been around for 9 years and as you can see from these
three charts the growth has been accelerating rapidly in the last several years alone so not only has this growth
increased but it's come from every organization that consumes
it in the startup Community AWS has been the default choice for some time AWS has
enabled T of thousands of startups to come out of nowhere and disrupt entire
Industries these are companies that you've probably heard of like redmart Property Guru Etsy Flipboard SmugMug and
thousands of others we're also seeing adoption spread quickly across
wellestablished it organizations so that they can remain competitive with these ambitious startups in the media
landscape my alma moer Dow Jones and News Corp became Cloud first and is in the process of migrating more than 50

following similar paths and Healthcare Bristol Meers squib is using AWS to run
computation intensive clinical trial simulations while reducing the cost and
the time to execute by several orders of magnitude MC is using AWS to operate
devops across a growing number of their business lines in the travel industry
quantis is using AWS to dynamically compute flight routing and to improve
their customer loyalty programs the weather company processing billions of weather events every single day
performing analytics on them and distributing them to to their millions of customer and financial services sun
corpor in Australia is also Cloud first and moving their estate to the cloud in
a very quick and big way we've got a few stories from some Singapore based companies which you're going to hear
from a little bit later and throughout our talk this morning when it comes down to it every imaginable business segment
is using AWS in a very meaningful way we've also been lucky enough to
build quite a public sector business over the course of the last several years there's more than 1,600 government
agencies all around the world using AWS to quickly procure and manage their it
assets as well as reduce deployment time and costs greatly many government
agencies are enjoying the benefit of having a common infrastructure across departments so that they can benefit
from the community effect the AWS Marketplace is allowing them to collaborate on package solution sols
across departments and consume solutions from thousands of Technology vendors all
through AWS which gra greatly reduces their often cumbersome bureaucratic
procurement processes in addition there's more than 3600 educational institutions all around
the world that are not only starting to use AWS for their it but are now also including it in the curriculum as
students are are learning how to use the platform much earlier on
so from the very beginning AWS knew that we would not be able to get sufficient reach for the business on our own so
there are a rich and growing set of Consulting partners that are available to help customers of all shapes and
sizes understand and implement the cloud into their business there's a fast and growing ecosystem of born in the cloud
providers like cloudreach and second watch and at this point all of the major consulting firms are growing Cloud
practices to help help their organizations understand what cloud means to them so a few months ago I had

environments similar to the Consulting Partners many of them are born in the cloud but there's also a growing number
of traditional it vendors like riverbed Splunk and sap and others who are making
very big bets to make their Solutions available in a cloud friendly way so
what does an accelerating growth of adoption powered by a large and diverse customer base and fueled by a large
partner Community translate into it puts AWS in the top right corner
while we sometimes feel a little bit lonely up there uh we are in fact committed to keeping it that
way now we weren't just satisfied knowing that we were growing very quickly we wanted to put this in the
context of the overall technology industry and what we found here was also
very encouraging looking at the multi-billion dollar Enterprise it companies in the world aw is growing at
over 40% year-over-year performing well above the pack while some of the traditional vendors are shrinking like
an IBM's Case by 12% now while there are many factors that contribute to this I feel that one
of the most important reasons is that AWS has given the power back to you the
customer I've been buying technology for a long time and I've always felt Hostage
to the technology that I've embedded into my systems licensing fees always got more expensive support always got
worse over time and efforts to move away often came with punitive terms in a
model where you pay only for what you use and only when you use it AWS has to fight hard to keep your business there's
nothing keeping you committed to our platform other than the service that you're getting from
AWS as a CIO I found this to be one of the most refreshing elements of the new world this is one of the main reasons I
came to work here and why it's so encouraging for me to see that cloud has in fact become The New Normal the
question is is no longer if we should move to the cloud it's what should we move first what order should we move our
applications in and how quickly can we move them the benefits that
organizations of all shapes and sizes have realized from adopting Cloud are so great that it's become impossible for
companies to ignore the cloud and expect to remain competitive so what does this new normal
look like what are some of the things that have led us to to conclude this this morning we're going to spend some
time talking about seven patterns that we've observed which illustrate how the cloud has indeed in fact become The New
Normal the first pattern is that speed is not just for startups I've had the
opportunity in this role to talk to cios all over the world and I usually hear a very similar story some move toward the
cloud to save money some to attain a global reach some to achieve better security posturing everybody would like
to move faster at the end of the day what AWS brings to large and established
organizations is the freedom from the undifferentiated heavy lifting that is traditionally associated with Enterprise
it the competitive landscape in every industry has become so great and there
are so many upand comers disrupting every industry who aren't weighed down with having to manage Legacy
infrastructure this makes it more important than ever before to remain laser focused on the
activities that drive your business forward and managing infrastructure is just not one of those things the
competition has no regard for your legacy and will continue to use it to their advantage whenever they
can in the old world procurement Cycles took a long time capacity planning was
hard and mistakes were expensive if you bought too much infrastructure you wasted money money
and may have tried to coers systems into the spare capacity even if it didn't really belong if you bought too little
even worse your customer suffered I can't tell you how many times in my career I've spearheaded millions of
dollars of investment only to watch it sit idle for long periods of time or
watch it become extinct by new technology almost immediately and certainly well before we were ready to
invest in it again in the new world you don't have to worry about over or under provisioning
since you're since you're paying only for what you use and when you use it your costs start incredibly low and
scale only with the success of your business at Dow Jones we went from having our capital projects average well
into the hundred thousands of dollars and take months sometimes years if they ever completed at all to having projects
come in bite-sized chunks of tens of thousands of dollars while being able to constantly iterate on the feedback that
we were receiving from customers in real time
also in the new world staying current is included with the price of admission AWS
has nearly doubled the number of features that it's brought to Market each of the last four years and you can
certainly expect that this pace of innovation is going to continue these are the kind of benefits that make it a
revenue generating hero rather than a slow-moving cost center so many
Enterprises are realizing this and embracing the fact that they can now behave like a startup Unilever is a
great example they moved 1,700 of their brand websites to our platform and are
moving 75% faster than they ever did before mint.com is a personal finance
site that that enjoys 15 million users across their platform they move their entire production site over to AWS
consuming about 700 ec2 instances a th000 EBS volumes and is having better

onto several other services on our platform to do real-time Whata if scenarios in the middle of

to better their business I'd like to invite up to the stage the CEO of globe

premium on the licensing fees for databases and once you start to use some of the proprietary features in the

take advantage of this by trying to squeeze more money out of you over time on top of this my my experience has

application to make up for shortcomings in the database layer so these are some of the reasons

with five times better performance than what you would likely achieve with my

existing Services which leads us to the fifth pattern of The New Normal which is again
another one of the reasons I was so excited to be at AWS it's no longer enough for technology vendors to come up
with one or two pieces of technology and ride the revenue that that brings in for
decades first of all the competition is too hungry but more importantly the
cloud has a enabled this model of continuous reinvention in the on- premises World it
takes a long time to roll out new enhancements and the effort to change always has to be stacked up against the
other projects that you need to engage in the cloud offers a substantial Improvement to this model AWS as we saw
before is constantly rolling out new features and enhancements to the platform which you can take advantage of
with absolutely no opportunity cost for example in 20 6 when AWS
launched ec2 we did so with one instance type the M M1 small this was certainly a

would best suit our needs each month and moving our applications around to optimize for both cost and

schedules so amidst this constant reinvention of compute we've seen another Trend arise over the last few
years we've learned that some developers want to have even smaller amounts of
compute that they can dedicate to services that they developed that have all of the necessary elements and
dependencies packaged together as one unit some developers have achieved
additional agility through managing a set of loosely coupled containers because they can be more confident when
changing individual components when the blast radius is wellknown and
predictable it's also easier to roll them out and back which further builds confidence
containers have also given companies the opportunity to optimize costs even further as they're able to run multiple
containers on individual instances this recent trend is why in
November AWS launched the preview for the Amazon ec2 container service in
partnership with Docker during the preview over the last few months we've had the opportunity to learn from
thousands of customers for how they're using it across a variety of different use cases and we've learned through that
experience to build in a number of new features that make managing containers on ec2 even easier this includes the
ability to launch containers across a cluster of ec2 instances attach persistent EBS volumes on container
launch and the ability for you to use your own private Docker repositories which is very important for companies

announce that the ec2 container service is now available for all customers and at the same time again we launch several
new features proving yet again that reinvention is continuous this included a new
Management console the expansion of the service into new regions and finally the
container service is also integrated into cloud trail so that you can gain additional transparency into your
containers and how they're running and one of the most exciting
features we added was a new scheduler to help you manage a fleet of containers
this scheduler allows you to quickly scale your containers Up and Down based on parameters you define distribute
traffic among them using an elastic load balancer just like you would ec2 instances automatically heal containers
that get into a bad State and it lets you deploy updates to your containers without ever taking the application down
we think that this scheduling service makes the ec2 container service the best
place in the world to run your containers in production and we're super excited to see what you'll build with

even less management overhead and and further lower costs based on the uniqueness of each application or

most revolutionary service that AWS has developed since the birth of cloud computing in
2006 AWS Lambda frees you of the burden of having to manage anything but your
own code you write code that responds to events from AWS and other services and
AWS will spin up all of the necessary resources required to run your code
running tens of thousands of them in parallel if required and the best part is you will only pay for the code that
executes in 100 millisecond increments I believe the possibilities
for this are endless and we've just only begun to scratch the surface we're seeing customers kick off
jobs or intelligence tasks when data changes in their environment it's an ideal service for handling requests from
your iot devices stream and workflow processing is another great example at Dow Jones we were looking to overhaul
our subscription management workflow platform which was a whole bunch of ec2 instances and services running on them
all managed through the simple workflow service and it was quite a lot of operations behind that complicated

container service and now to Lambda is the kind of reinvention that's become
